metadata.case_name: Religious Head of Dawoodi Bohra Community (Appellant) v. Tyebbhai Moosaji Koicha and State of Bombay

facts.text: On July 17, 1920, the appellant excommunicated two persons, Tahirbhai and Hasan Ali.

The validity of the 1920 excommunication order was questioned in a suit before the Subordinate Judge, Barhampur, which went to Privy Council; held that appellant had power to excommunicate but only after observing requisite formalities, and as not done, order invalid. Vide Hasan Ali v. Mansoorali, A.I.R. 1948 P.C. 66.
On February 28, 1934, the appellant passed an order excommunicating Tyebbhai Moosaji Koicha.
Apprehending challenge under Hasan Ali decision for non-compliance with formalities, appellant on April 28, 1948, passed another order excommunicating Tyebbhai Moosaji Koicha.
Tyebbhai Moosaji filed Original Suit No. 1262 of 1949 for declaration that both excommunication orders dated February 28, 1934, and April 28, 1948, were invalid and for consequential reliefs.
Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act (Bombay XLII of 1949) passed, prohibiting excommunication, came into force on November 1, 1949.
Plaintiff contended orders illegal due to the 1949 Act.

Appellant contended Act had no retrospective operation, orders valid; Act unconstitutional as not covered by Lists 2 or 3 of Seventh Schedule to Government of India Act, 1935; post-Constitution, protected by Arts. 25 and 26.

Issue No. 19 framed: Whether the orders of excommunication made in 1934 and/or 1948 are invalid by reason of the provisions of the Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act of 1949? Tried as preliminary issue; State of Bombay impleaded as second defendant.
Shah J. held Act retrospective, within competence of Provincial Legislature, did not offend Arts. 25 and 26.

Appeal to Bombay High Court (Appeal No. 43 of 1952 from judgment dated August 20, 1952); Chagla C.J. and Bhagwati J. held excommunication a continuing state, Act protects rights from date of operation; within competence, no infringement of Arts. 25/26; dismissed appeal, granted certificate under Arts. 132/133.
Plaintiff Tyebbhai Moosaji died on March 11, 1953; daughter applied May 22, 1953 to substitute, not pressed, dismissed October 5, 1953.
In Supreme Court, cause title amended November 21, 1955, deleting plaintiff's name; only defendant (appellant) and State of Bombay before Court.
No decree passed in suit; only finding on preliminary issue; other issues pending.

legal_issues.text: Whether the orders of excommunication dated 1934 and 1948 are invalid by reason of the Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act, 1949 (Issue No. 19).
Whether the Act is retrospective in operation.
Whether Provincial Legislature competent to enact the Act (not covered by Lists 2/3 of Seventh Schedule, GOI Act 1935).
Whether Act violates Arts. 25 and 26 of Constitution.
Whether appeal maintainable after abatement of suit due to plaintiff's death, with only State as party.

petitioner_arguments.text: Act had no retrospective operation; orders of 1934 and 1948 valid and unaffected.
Act unconstitutional, not covered by entries in List 2 or 3 of Seventh Schedule to GOI Act 1935; Provincial Legislature lacked competence.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Seventh Schedule, Lists 2/3, Government of India Act, 1935

petitioner_arguments.text: Right to excommunicate protected by Arts. 25 and 26; Act void.
Appeal can continue against State of Bombay alone for decision on vires, as State impleaded; relies on United Provinces v. Mst. Atiqa Begum.

respondent_arguments.text: Act retrospective or operates on continuing state of excommunication from date of operation.
Act does not infringe Arts. 25 and 26.

court_reasoning.text: Suit is personal action (wrongful excommunication); on plaintiff's death, abates under actio personalis moritur cum persona; legal rep not substituted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No decree passed, only preliminary finding; other issues pending.

court_reasoning.text: Appeal cannot continue as suit abated; appeal is continuation of suit, which does not exist.
court_reasoning.key_observation: United Provinces v. Atiqa Begum inapplicable as there was a decree.

court_reasoning.text: Order not judgment, decree or final order under Art. 132; not final as even if Act invalid, other issues remain; Explanation to Art. 132 not satisfied.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Certificate under Arts. 132/133 does not confer jurisdiction.

holdings.text: Appeal not maintainable and must be dismissed.

precedents_cited.relevance: Held religious head has power to excommunicate but only after formalities; prompted second excommunication order.

precedents_cited.case_name: United Provinces v. Mst. Atiqa Begum and others
precedents_cited.relevance: Government could appeal on vires despite no interest in suit claim, as decree existed under s.205 GOI Act; inapplicable here as no decree, suit abated.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Central to validity of excommunication orders; vires challenged.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Protection of religious rights; appellate jurisdiction.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Scope of appeals narrower than s.205 GOI Act.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed as not maintainable due to abatement of suit upon plaintiff's death without substitution, absence of decree or final order, and interlocutory nature of finding on preliminary issue under Arts. 132/133.

key_quotes.text: On the principle, actio personalis moritur cum persona when he died the suit should abate.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: an appeal is only a continuation of the suit, and there can be no question of continuing what does not exist.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: We are clearly of opinion that the appeal is not competent under Art. 132, and the fact that a certificate has been given does not alter the position.
key_quotes.speaker: court
